body.p: supports SVG templates images (with .template.svg extension). These files can contain XPath expressions that will be expanded by the processor.

section.title: Using SVG Template as Cover Page
section.p:
Let's illustrate with an example:
The following HTML file should be printed with a cover page:<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE html> <html xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"> <head> <title>How to Dynamically add Content to SVG</title> <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css"/> <meta name="author" content="John Doe"/> <meta name="version" content="1.1"/> <meta name="copyright" content="Â© Oxygen PDF Chemistry. For demonstration purpose."/> </head> <body> ... </body> </html>
The cover page should display meta nodes information and the main title. Both author and version will be displayed in rectangles shapes prefixed with the displayed information ("Author:" and "Version"):<svg width="8.5in" height="11in" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"> <g> <rect height="39" width="180" y="40" x="579" stroke="#000" fill="#fff"/> <rect height="39" width="180" y="79" x="579" stroke="#000" fill="#fff"/> <text font-size="8" stroke-width="0" y="52" x="582" stroke="#000" fill="#000000" >Author:</text> <text font-size="16" stroke-width="0" y="66" x="643" stroke="#000" fill="#000000" >${//meta[@name='author']/@content}</text> <text font-size="8" stroke-width="0" y="91" x="582" stroke="#000" fill="#000000" >Version:</text> <text font-size="16" stroke-width="0" y="104" x="659" stroke="#000" fill="#000000" >${//meta[@name='version']/@content}</text> <text font-size="30" stroke-width="0" y="252" x="123" stroke="#000" fill="#000000" >${//head/title}</text> <text font-size="12" stroke-width="0" y="993.40002" x="266" stroke="#000" fill="#000000" >${//meta[@name='copyright']/@content}</text> </g> </svg>
The templates aren't expanded if the SVG is opened in Author mode.
The templates can be tested (without ${}) using XPath/XQuery Builder view.
The CSS stylesheet should declare a synthetic page before the HTML document to be printed and display the SVG cover image on this new page:@page cover-page { background-image: url('cover.svg'); background-repeat: no-repeat; }
html::before { content: " "; page: cover-page; }
